title: Ex Country Garden, Risland wins court case against Bradcorp
text:
The court win works in Risland's favour as the company restructures its buying strategy and relinquishes some of its previous land commitments including another 365-hectare rural site in nearby Cawdor which it is selling.

In the Bradcorp case, the NSW Supreme Court ruled Bradcorp had not fulfilled two of the three required "conditions precedent" (CPs) of rezoning, mining leases, and access that would allow Risland to go ahead with the transaction.

While Bradcorp had obtained a residential rezoning last December it didn't properly complete the surrender of mining leases on the land and wasn't able to get access to the property from the Hume Motorway which connects with the center of Sydney.

Part of Bradcorp's difficulty in getting access to the land from the motorway is Lendlease's refusal to sell a parcel of its land joining Wilton North and the motorway for roadworks.

Lendlease already had its own plans, having lodged a development application for more housing on the site.

"In this context, what was required was a zoning which would in effect dedicate the land to building the required road works, not a zoning where Lendlease would have a choice either to build the road works or to use it for building houses instead," Justice Parker said.

"In my view, Lendlease’s subsequent conduct is the very sort of thing the parties were seeking, by the zoning requirement, to avoid."
description: Risland has succeeded in defending its decision not to go ahead with the option to purchase Bradcorp's 870-hectare rural site at Wilton North.
